Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Situation2: Pre-dawn traffic is sparse and holding patterns are empty.
Story: The phone vibrates on the console, my partner’s name lighting up the screen. I know why he’s calling—he lost his brother last night, and I promised I’d be there for him, no matter what. My heart aches to answer, to be the comfort he needs, but my headset crackles with the voices of pilots checking in. The pre-dawn sky is quiet, the radar almost empty, but I can’t let my guard down. Even one mistake could be catastrophic. My supervisor expects unwavering focus, and the pilots trust me to keep them safe. Yet, every second I don’t pick up, I imagine him alone in the dark, needing me. I stare at the blinking call, torn between the duty to hundreds of lives in the sky and the one person who needs me most on the ground. My hands hover, one over the phone, the other on the radio, my chest tight with the weight of both worlds pressing in.
